prefix: You are an expert in number theory. Solve the following problem.
problem_prompt: You are an expert in number theory. Solve the following problem. Every 5 months, Hal has to replace the batteries in his calculator. He changed them the first time in May. In what month will they be changed the 25th time?
solution: If the first time was in May, the second time will be 5 months after May, the third time will be $5\cdot2$ months after May, etc. That means the 25th time will be $5\cdot24$ months away. Since the months repeat every 12 months, we look for the remainder when $5\cdot24$ is divided by 12 and add that many months to May. We notice that $\frac{5\cdot24}{12}=5\cdot2$, so it turns out that $5\cdot24$ is a multiple of 12 and leaves a remainder of 0 when divided by 12. So the 25th time will be a certain number of years afterward but still in the same month, $\boxed{\text{May}}$.
gpt_response:
Since Hal changes the batteries every 5 months, we can find the month in which he will change them the 25th time by calculating the remainder when 25 is divided by 12 (the number of months in a year).

25 divided by 12 gives a remainder of 1. This means that after changing the batteries 24 times (12 months x 2 = 24 months), he will have changed them the 25th time in the month following May, which is **June**.
solution_prompt:
The following is a response to a question. Yes or no, is the final solution obtained in the following response \text{May?: Since Hal changes the batteries every 5 months, we can find the month in which he will change them the 25th time by calculating the remainder when 25 is divided by 12 (the number of months in a year).

25 divided by 12 gives a remainder of 1. This means that after changing the batteries 24 times (12 months x 2 = 24 months), he will have changed them the 25th time in the month following May, which is **June**.
